LayoutNode.Content: Shellharden Shellharden is a syntax highlighter and a tool to semi-automate the rewriting of scripts toShellCheck conformance, mainly focused on quoting.
LayoutNode.SRC:
Shellharden

Shellharden is a syntax highlighter and a tool to semi-automate the rewriting of scripts to ShellCheck conformance, mainly focused on quoting.

LayoutNode.Content: The default mode of operation is like cat , but with syntax highlighting in foreground colors and suggestive changes in
LayoutNode.SRC: The default mode of operation is like cat, but with syntax highlighting in foreground colors and suggestive changes in
background colors:

LayoutNode.Content: Above: Selected portions of xdg-desktop-menu as highlighted by Shellharden. The foreground colors are syntax highlighting,
LayoutNode.SRC: Above: Selected portions of xdg-desktop-menu as highlighted by Shellharden. The foreground colors are syntax highlighting,

LayoutNode.Content: whereas the background colors (green and red) show characters that Shellharden would have added or removed if let loose with
LayoutNode.SRC: whereas the background colors (green and red) show characters that Shellharden would have added or removed if let loose with

LayoutNode.Content: the --transform option. Below: An artificial example that shows more tricky cases and special features.
LayoutNode.SRC: the --transform option. Below: An artificial example that shows more tricky cases and special features.

LayoutNode.Content: A variable in bash is like a hand grenade â€“ take off its quotes, and it starts ticking. Hence, rule zero of bash pitfalls : Always use quotes.
LayoutNode.SRC: A variable in bash is like a hand grenade â€“ take off its quotes, and it starts ticking. Hence, rule zero of bash pitfalls: Always usequotes.

LayoutNode.Content: Shellharden can do what Shellcheck can't: Apply the suggested changes.
LayoutNode.SRC: Shellharden can do what Shellcheck can't: Apply the suggested changes.

LayoutNode.Content: In other words, harden brittle shellscripts. The builtin assumption is that the script does not depend on the brittle behavior â€“ the user is responsible for the code review.
LayoutNode.SRC: In other words, harden brittle shellscripts. The builtin assumption is that the script does not depend on the brittle behavior â€“ theuser is responsible for the code review.

LayoutNode.Content: Shellharden was previously known as "Naziquote". In the right jargon, that was the best name ever, but oh so misleading andunspeakable to outsiders.
LayoutNode.SRC: Shellharden was previously known as "Naziquote". In the right jargon, that was the best name ever, but oh so misleading and unspeakable to outsiders.

LayoutNode.Content: I couldn't call it "bash cleaner" either, as that means "poo smearer" in Norwegian.
LayoutNode.SRC: I couldn't call it "bash cleaner" either, as that means "poo smearer" in Norwegian.
Prior art

LayoutNode.Content: Shellcheck is a wonderful tool to detect , and give general advice, about brittle bash code. The only thing missing is something to say yes with, and apply those advice (assuming proper review of course). I asked this SO question , for a tool that could rewrite bash scripts with proper quoting. One answerer beat me to it. But if it was me, I would do a syntax highlighter in the same tool (as a way to see if the parser gets lost, and make the most out of the parser, because bash is like quantum mechanics â€“ nobody really knows how it works).
LayoutNode.SRC: Shellcheck is a wonderful tool to detect, and give general advice, about brittle bash code. The only thing missing is somethingto say yes with, and apply those advice (assuming proper review of course).I asked this SO question, for a tool that could rewrite bash scripts with proper quoting. One answerer beat me to it. But if itwas me, I would do a syntax highlighter in the same tool (as a way to see if the parser gets lost, and make the most out of theparser, because bash is like quantum mechanics â€“ nobody really knows how it works).
Install from package
Plan A: Distro package:
ArchHomebrew

LayoutNode.Content: Plan B: The official shellharden rust package :
LayoutNode.SRC: Plan B: The official shellharden rust package:
cargo install shellharden

LayoutNode.Content: Plan C: Use this docker image directly:
LayoutNode.SRC: Plan C: Use this docker image directly:
cat shellscript.sh | docker run -i --rm sbkg0002/shellharden:4.0 ''

LayoutNode.Content: Shameless plug: Docker is the wrong tool for this job. For greater speed and (supposedly) security, unpack the docker image once and for all and use selfdock instead.
LayoutNode.SRC: Shameless plug: Docker is the wrong tool for this job. For greater speed and (supposedly) security, unpack the docker image onceand for all and use selfdock instead.
Build from source
cargo build --release
Run tests
cargo test --release
(requires bash)
cp target/release/shellharden /usr/local/bin/
Build docker image
docker build -t shellgarden .
Fuzz test

LayoutNode.Content: cargo install afl cargo afl build --release cargo afl fuzz -i moduletests/original -o /tmp/fuzz-shellharden target/release/shellharden '@@'
LayoutNode.SRC: cargo install afl cargo afl build --release cargo afl fuzz -i moduletests/original -o /tmp/fuzz-shellharden target/release/shellharden '@@' cargo install afl cargo afl build --release cargo afl fuzz -i moduletests/original -o /tmp/fuzz-shellharden target/release/shellharden '@@' cargo install afl cargo afl build --release cargo afl fuzz -i moduletests/original -o /tmp/fuzz-shellharden target/release/shellharden '@@'
Usage advice

LayoutNode.Content: Don't apply --transform blindly; code review is still necessary: A script that relies on unquoted behavior (implicit word splitting
LayoutNode.SRC: Don't apply --transform blindly; code review is still necessary: A script that relies on unquoted behavior (implicit word splitting

LayoutNode.Content: and glob expansion from variables and command substitutions) to work as intended will do none of that after getting the
LayoutNode.SRC: and glob expansion from variables and command substitutions) to work as intended will do none of that after getting the
--transform treatment!

LayoutNode.Content: In that unlucky case, ask yourself whether the script has any business in doing that. All too often, it's just a product of classical shellscripting, and would be better off rewritten, such as by using arrays. Even in the opposite case, say the business logic involves word splitting; that can still be done without invoking globbing. In short: There is always a better way than the forbidden syntax (if not more explicit), but some times, a human must step in to rewrite. See how, in the accompanying how to do things safely in bash .
LayoutNode.SRC: In that unlucky case, ask yourself whether the script has any business in doing that. All too often, it's just a product of classicalshellscripting, and would be better off rewritten, such as by using arrays. Even in the opposite case, say the business logic involvesword splitting; that can still be done without invoking globbing. In short: There is always a better way than the forbidden syntax (ifnot more explicit), but some times, a human must step in to rewrite. See how, in the accompanying how to do things safely in bashhow to do things safely in bash.
